awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Reversible plasticity in nanocrystalline metals and alloys for shape memory applications
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Nanocrystalline materials are composed of crystallites (grains) that have an average size of about 100 nanometers or less. The small grain size leads to very high strength, which has led to significant interest in using these materials for structural applications. But in addition to their exceptional strength, nanocrystalline materials also exhibit several intriguing properties including the ability to recover plastic deformation, which is typically considered to be irrecoverable. This CAREER award supports fundamental research that aims to exploit this unusual deformation recovery in nanocrystalline metals and alloys for shape memory related applications. In essence, the project lays the foundation to employ nanocrystalline metals and alloys as smart, functional materials that have applications in aerospace, medicine and robotics. The research activity is integrated with a broad effort to promote materials science education at multiple levels. These education and outreach efforts include a new mentoring program and scientific demonstrations for high school students, teacher workshops, course enhancements, and training of undergraduate and graduate students in multidisciplinary materials research. 

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Conventionally, plastic deformation is considered to be permanent. However, nanocrystalline materials can recover a large fraction of plastic strain after unloading by thermal activation. This project explores the fundamental aspects of this unusual strain recovery and seeks to determine whether complete strain recovery can be repeatedly obtained in nanocrystalline metals and alloys by controlling their microstructure. The research efforts are directed towards two distinct goals: 1) Characterizing the repeatability and temperature dependence of strain recovery in nanocrystalline face centered cubic metals and alloys over multiple cycles and 2) Understanding how the interplay between material properties (elastic and plastic anisotropy, stacking fault energy) and microstructural heterogeneity (variation in size and orientation of grains) affects the strain recovery characteristics and mechanisms. These goals are pursued using novel, micro-electro-mechanical systems based thermomechanical testing and in situ transmission electron microscopy straining experiments on nanocrystalline metal and alloy films with controlled microstructures.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The primary objectives of the project were to characterize and understand the mechanisms of plastic strain recovery in heterogeneous nanocrystalline metal films. The research conducted in this project has resulted in the following major outcomes/conclusions.

1. Copper-Cobalt nanolaminates recover a significant fraction of plastic strain after unloading. The strain recovery is maximized at a layer thickness of 4 nanometers.

2. Strain recovery in ultrafine-grained aluminum films during unloading is caused by reversible grain rotations, as revealed by in-situ transmission electron microscopy experiments.

3. Aluminum thin films with a heterogeneous microstructure recover a substantially larger fraction of plastic strain compared to films with a homogeneous microstructure, irrespective of the applied strain rate.

4. The stress-strain response of aluminum thin films with a heterogeneous microstructure is considerably more sensitive to strain rate compared to films with a homogeneous microstructure.

5. Ni films with a heterogeneous nanotwinned microstructure exhibit both high strength and good ductility.

6. NiTi thin films with nanocrystalline and ultrafine-grained microstructure show a combination of shape memory and pseudoelastic effect.

7. Electron beam exposure during in-situ TEM straining causes a marked change in the stress-strain response of nanocrystalline metal films.

8. A new method to create metallic films with precisely defined multimodal microstructures has been developed.

9. The interplay between the geometry of dislocation slip and the spatial orientation of coarse domains is critical to the mechanical behavior of iron films with bimodal architectures.

10. Heterostructured metal films do not exhibit the strength-ductility synergy observed in bulk heterostructured metals.

These findings have been disseminated to the research community through 15 publications in archival journals and more than 10 conference presentations. Two US patents have been granted for new thin film processing methods developed during the project. A provisional US patent application has also been filed.

The project has had a substantial impact in terms of human capital development by supporting the PhD thesis of two students. During the course of the project, the students developed skills related to thin film deposition and characterization, microfabrication, in situ materials testing and data analysis. Both students are now employed as a research and development engineers in a major semiconductor manufacturing firm.

The education and outreach activities enabled by the project introduced more than 500 high school students and 100 first-year engineering students at Arizona State University to microscale materials testing and mechanical behavior of materials.

 


Last Modified: 10/25/2022
Modified by: Jagannathan Rajagopalan
